<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: public class TestStringTokenStrict {
```csharp
/**
 * Strict implementation of StringTokenizer
 * 
 * @param str
 * @param delim
 *            true = include NULL Token
 * @return
 */
static StringTokenizer getStringTokenizerStrict(String str, String delim, boolean strict) {
    StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(str, delim, strict);
    StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();

    while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
        String s = st.nextToken();
        if (s.equals(delim)) {
            sb.append(" ").append(delim);
        } else {
            sb.append(s).append(delim);
            if (st.hasMoreTokens())
                st.nextToken();
        }
    }
    return (new StringTokenizer(sb.toString(), delim));
}

static void altStringTokenizer(StringTokenizer st) {
    while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
        String type = st.nextToken();
        String one = st.nextToken();
        String two = st.nextToken();
        String three = st.nextToken();
        String four = st.nextToken();
        String five = st.nextToken();

        System.out.println(
                "[" + type + "] [" + one + "] [" + two + "] [" + three + "] [" + four + "] [" + five + "]");
    }
}

public static void main(String[] args) {
    String input = "Record|One||Three||Five";
    altStringTokenizer(getStringTokenizerStrict(input, "|", true));
}
```
}

In this code, the `altStringTokenizer` method is used to print out the tokens extracted from the `getStringTokenizerStrict` method. The `getStringTokenizerStrict` method is a strict implementation of the `StringTokenizer` class that includes NULL tokens in the output. The `altStringTokenizer` method simply prints out the tokens as they are extracted.

To answer your original question, you can modify the `altStringTokenizer` method to check for empty tokens and print them out if they exist. Here is an example of how you can do this:

<<<code>>>: public class TestStringTokenStrict {
```csharp
/**
 * Strict implementation of StringTokenizer
 * 
 * @param str
 * @param delim
 *            true = include NULL Token
 * @return
 */
static StringTokenizer getStringTokenizerStrict(String str, String delim, boolean strict) {
    StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(str, delim, strict);
    StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();

    while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
        String s = st.nextToken();
        if (s.equals(delim)) {
            sb.append(" ").append(delim);
        } else {
            sb.append(s).append(delim);
            if (st.hasMoreTokens())
                st.nextToken();
        }
    }
    return (new StringTokenizer(sb.toString(), delim));
}

static void altStringTokenizer(StringTokenizer st) {
    while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
        String type = st.nextToken();
        String one = st.nextToken();
        String two = st.nextToken();
        String three = st.nextToken();
        String four = st.nextToken();
        String five = st.nextToken();

        if (one.equals("")) {
            System.out.println("Empty field found: " + one);
        } else {
            System.out.println(
                    "[" + type + "] [" + one + "] [" + two + "] [" + three + "] [" + four + "] [" + five + "]");
        }
    }
}

public static void main(String[] args) {
    String input = "Record|One||Three||Five";
    altStringTokenizer(getStringTokenizerStrict(input, "|", true));
}
```

In this modified code, the `altStringTokenizer` method checks if the first token in each group is empty.
